F.C.|PAOK Thessaloniki]] *UEFA Cup first round (tie decided over one leg only, because of general strike in Israel last week): **'''[[SC Heerenveen|Heerenveen]]''' 5 – 0 [[Maccabi Petach Tikva FC|Maccabi Petach Tikva]]
==September 29, 2004== * More than three decades after the [[Washington Senators (1961–71)|Washington Senators]] were moved away from Washington, D.C., city officials there announce that [[Major League Baseball]] will return to the city in 2005: the city's [[Washington Nationals|relocation bid]] for the [[Montreal Expos]] has been accepted, ending years of uncertainty about the future of that franchise. (5 p.m. EDT) *[[UEFA Champions League]], Group Stage, Matchday 2 **Group E: [[PSV Eindhoven|PSV]] 1 – 0 [[Panathinaikos F.C.|Panathinaikos]] **Group E: [[Rosenborg BK|Rosenborg]] 1 – 1 [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] **Group F: [[FC Barcelona]] 3 – 0 [[FC Shakhtar Donetsk|Shakhtar Donetsk]] **Group F: [[A.C. Milan]] 3 – 1 [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] **Group G: [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] 1 – 3 [[Internazionale Milano F.C.|Inter Milan]] **Group G: [[Werder Bremen]] 2 – 1 [[Valencia C.F.|Valencia]] **Group H: [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] 3 – 1 [[F.C. Porto]] **Group H: [[PFC CSKA Moskva|CSKA Moscow]] 2 – 0 [[Paris Saint Germain]]
==September 28, 2004== *[[UEFA Champions League]], Group Stage, Matchday 2 **Group A: [[AS Monaco FC|AS Monaco]] 2 – 0 [[Deportivo de La Coruña|Deportivo La Coruña]] **Group A: [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]] 1 – 0 [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] **Group B: [[Dynamo Kyiv]] 4 – 2 [[Bayer Leverkusen]] **Group B: [[Real Madrid]] 4 – 2 [[AS Roma]] **Group C: [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]] 4 – 0 [[Ajax Amsterdam|Ajax]] **Group C: [[Juventus]] 1 – 0 [[Maccabi Tel Aviv FC|Maccabi Tel Aviv]] **Group D: [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] 6 – 2 [[Fenerbahçe SK|Fenerbahçe]] **Group D: [[AC Sparta Praha|Sparta Prague]] 1 – 2 [[Olympique Lyonnais]]
==September 27, 2004== [[File:WNBA Sue Bird cropped.jpg|thumb|180px| [[Sue Bird]], on offense]] * [[Basketball]]: ** The [[New Orleans Hornets]] announce that [[Jamal Mashburn]] will not play in the 2004–2005 [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] season because of a knee injury. [http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=1889785 (ESPN)] ** [[Sue Bird]] breaks her nose and requires a brief visit to a hospital, but her [[Seattle Storm]] win their first [[Women's National Basketball Association|WNBA]] playoff series ever, beating the [[Minnesota Lynx]] 64–54 to win their opening round series, 2 games to 0. [http://sports.espn.go.com/wnba/recap?gameId=240927014 (ESPN)] ** [[Diana Taurasi]] of the [[Phoenix Mercury]] is named the WNBA's rookie of the year. [http://espn.go.com/wnba/news/2004/0927/1890112.html (ESPN)] * [[Baseball]]: The [[Boston Red Sox]] clinch a playoff berth by defeating the [[Tampa Bay Devil Rays]], 7 runs to 3. [http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/recap?gameId=240927130 (ESPN)] * [[National Football League]] Week 3, [[Monday Night Football]]: The [[Dallas Cowboys]] spoil [[Joe Gibbs]]' return to ''MNF'' with a 21 to 18 win over the [[Washington Redskins]].
==September 26, 2004== * [[Formula One]]: The inaugural [[Chinese Grand Prix]] in Shanghai entertains the crowd of nearly 200,000 with an exciting race, won by Brazilian [[Rubens Barrichello]], separated by less than 1.5 seconds from second place [[United Kingdom|Briton]] [[Jenson Button]] and [[Finland|Finn]] [[Kimi Räikkönen]] in third place. [http://sport.guardian.co.uk/formulaone/story/0,10069,1313456,00.html (Guardian)] * [[National Football League]] Week 3: ** [[Peyton Manning]] throws for five touchdowns and [[Brett Favre]] throws his 4000th completion as the [[Indianapolis Colts]] defeat the [[Green Bay Packers]] 45–31. [https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/recap?gid=20040926011 (Yahoo!/AP)] ** [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] receiver [[Tim Brown (American football)|Tim Brown]] catches his 100th career touchdown pass in a game against his former team, the [[Oakland Raiders]]. [https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/boxscore?gid=20040926013 (Yahoo!/AP)] ** The [[San Francisco 49ers]] are shut out for the first time since 1977 in a 34–0 loss to the [[Seattle Seahawks]]. [https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/recap?gid=20040926026 (Yahoo!/AP)] ** The [[Jacksonville Jaguars]] are 3–0 for the first time since 1998 after a last-second 15–12 win over the [[Tennessee Titans]]. [https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/recap?gid=20040926010 (Yahoo!/AP)] ** The [[Kansas City Chiefs]] likewise fall to 0–3 after being beat in the final seconds by the [[Houston Texans]], 24–21. [https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/recap?gid=20040926012 (Yahoo!/AP)] **[[Morten Andersen]] of the [[Minnesota Vikings]] makes an appearance in the Vikings' game against the [[Chicago Bears]], marking his 341st appearance in an [[National Football League|NFL]] game, and breaking [[George Blanda]]'s record. Blanda played with the Bears and the [[Oakland Raiders]]. Besides the Vikings, Andersen has played for the [[New Orleans Saints]], the [[Atlanta Falcons]], the [[New York Giants]] and the [[Kansas City Chiefs]]. ([http://bears.theinsiders.com/2/298962.html Chicago Bear Report])
==September 25, 2004== * [[Boxing]]: [[Glen Johnson (boxer)|Glen Johnson]] retains his [[International Boxing Federation|IBF]] [[light heavyweight|light heavyweight title]] by [[knockout|knocking out]] [[Roy Jones, Jr.]] in the ninth round. Jones' record now stands 49–3–0 while Johnson stands for 41–9–2. [http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/news/story?id=1888952 (ESPN)] * [[Riddick Bowe]] makes a triumphant return to the sport after an eight-year hiatus, knocking out [[Marcus Rhode]] in two rounds. * [[ICC Champions Trophy 2004|Cricket, ICC Champions Trophy]]: The [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies]] defeat [[England cricket team|England]] in the final at [[The Oval]] by two wickets with seven balls to spare. It's their first major tournament victory since the 1979 [[Cricket World Cup|World Cup]]. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/other_international/3686700.stm (BBC)] * [[Australian rules football|Aussie rules]]: The [[Port Adelaide Football Club]] win their first [[Australian Football League|AFL]] championship by ending the [[Brisbane Lions]]' three-year run as champions 113 to 73 at [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] in [[Melbourne]]. * [[National Football League]]: The [[Miami Dolphins]] are forced to reschedule a home game for the second time in three weeks due to a [[hurricane]]. Their game against the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] is being moved from 1:00 on Sunday, September 26 to 8:30 because of the threat of [[Hurricane Jeanne]]. [https://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/2004-09-25-jeanne-ppd_x.htm?POE=SPOISVA (USA Today)]
==September 24, 2004== * [[Baseball]]: [[Boston Red Sox|Boston]] [[pitcher]] [[Pedro Martínez]] earns a no-decision after a poor showing in his last start as the Red Sox lose to the [[New York Yankees]] 6 to 4 at [[Fenway Park]] in [[Boston]]. * [[Women's boxing]]: [[Laila Ali]] wins the IWBF Light Heavyweight title, knocking out [[Gwendolyn O'Neal]] in three rounds, at [[Atlanta]].
==September 23, 2004== * [[Baseball]]: [[Baltimore Orioles|Baltimore]] second baseman [[Brian Roberts (baseball)|Brian Roberts]] hit his 48th [[Double (baseball)|double]] of the season, breaking the franchise record set by [[Cal Ripken, Jr.]] in 1983. * [[Boxing]]: [[James Toney]] scores an eighth-round knockdown, on his way to a twelve-round unanimous decision win over [[Rydell Booker]]. [http://www.boxing-central.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=4990 (BoxingCentral)]
==September 22, 2004== * [[Football (soccer)]]: Today's scheduled [[UEFA Cup]] First round, first leg, match between [[Maccabi Petach Tikva FC|Maccabi Petach-Tikva]] and [[SC Heerenveen|Heerenveen]] is cancelled when a general strike in [[Israel]] prevents the Dutch team from travelling to the match. The tie will be decided by one match in the Netherlands on September 30, when the [[away goals rule]] will not apply. [http://www.uefa.com/competitions/UEFACup/news/Kind=1/newsId=233589.html (UEFA.com)] * [[ICC Champions Trophy 2004|Cricket, ICC Champions Trophy]]: In the second semi-final at [[Rose Bowl (cricket ground)|The Rose Bowl]], the [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies]] beat [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan]] by seven wickets. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/3680750.stm (BBC)]
==September 21, 2004== * [[Football (soccer)]]: [[UEFA]] ruled that the September 15 [[UEFA Champions League]] fixture in Rome between [[Dynamo Kyiv]] and [[A.S. Roma|AS Roma]], abandoned at halftime when referee [[Anders Frisk]] was hit by an object thrown onto the field, would be a 3–0 forfeit win to Dynamo Kyiv. Roma will be required to play its next two home Champions League fixtures, against [[Bayer Leverkusen]] on November 3 and [[Real Madrid]] on November 8, with no spectators. [http://soccernet.espn.go.com/headlinenews?id=310936&cc=5901 (ESPN Soccernet)] * [[ICC Champions Trophy 2004|Cricket, ICC Champions Trophy]]: In the first semi-final at [[Edgbaston Cricket Ground|Edgbaston]], [[England cricket team|England]] beat [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] by six wickets. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/other_international/3677690.stm (BBC)]
==September 20, 2004==
* [[Football (soccer)]]: [[Real Madrid]] manager [[José Antonio Camacho]] resigns. * [[National Football League]] Week 2, [[Monday Night Football]]: [[Philadelphia Eagles]] [[quarterback]] [[Donovan McNabb]] goes 19 for 28 with 245 yards and two [[touchdown]]s as the Eagles defeat the [[Minnesota Vikings]] 27 to 16.
==September 19, 2004== * [[Golf]]: In the final day's play in the [[2004 Ryder Cup]], [[Lee Westwood]] sinks the putt that ensures that Europe retains the Ryder Cup, and [[Colin Montgomerie]] sinks the putt that gives Team Europe an outright victory, as the European team defeats the United States of America 18½ to 9½. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/golf/3670968.stm (BBC)] * [[ICC Champions Trophy 2004|Cricket, ICC Champions Trophy]]: In pool C, [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan]] beat [[India national cricket team|India]] by three wickets at [[Edgbaston Cricket Ground|Edgbaston]]. In the held-over pool B match from yesterday, the [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies]] beat [[South Africa national cricket team|South Africa]] by five wickets at [[The Oval]]. Both Pakistan and the West Indies now qualify for the semi-finals. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/other_international/3670542.stm (BBC)] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/other_international/3666028.stm (BBC)] * [[American football]]: Week 2 of the [[National Football League|NFL]] season ** The [[Arizona Cardinals]] retire the #40 of [[Pat Tillman]] at halftime of their game against the [[New England Patriots]] at [[Tempe, Arizona]]. ** [[Tom Coughlin]] gets his first win as head coach of the [[New York Giants]], 20 to 14, over the [[Washington Redskins]]. [https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/recap?gid=20040919019 (Yahoo! Sports)] **[[Jerry Rice]]'s record of 274 consecutive games with a [[pass reception]] comes to an end, although his [[Oakland Raiders]] defeat the [[Buffalo Bills]], 13–10. ([http://msnbc.msn.com/id/6048897/ MSNBC])
==September 18, 2004== * [[Boxing]]: [[Bernard Hopkins]] retains his [[International Boxing Federation|IBF]], [[World Boxing Association|WBA]], and [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] world Middleweight titles, while adding the [[WBO]] one, knocking out [[Oscar De La Hoya]] in nine rounds
==Science== * [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]]. It is de la Hoya's first career knockout loss. * [[Golf]]: After the second day's play in the [[2004 Ryder Cup]], Europe leads the United States 11–5. The U.S. took the morning's fourballs 2½ to 1½, and Europe won the afternoon's foursomes 3–1. Europe needs just three points from Sunday's twelve singles matches to retain the trophy. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/golf/3669748.stm (BBC)] * [[ICC Champions Trophy 2004|Cricket, ICC Champions Trophy]]: In pool D, [[England cricket team|England]] beat [[Sri Lanka national cricket team|Sri Lanka]] by 49 runs on the [[Duckworth–Lewis method]] after rain caused the match to be abandoned before Sri Lanka's innings was complete. England now qualify for the semi-finals. The pool B match between [[South Africa national cricket team|South Africa]] and the [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies]] is also interrupted by rain and will conclude tomorrow. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/3666882.stm (BBC)]
==September 17, 2004 ==
* [[2004 Summer Paralympics]]: The opening ceremony takes place in [[Athens]], Greece. * [[Golf]]: Europe leads the United States 6½ to 1½ at the end of the first day of the [[2004 Ryder Cup|35th Ryder Cup Matches]] at [[Oakland Hills Country Club]] in suburban [[Detroit]]. Europe led the morning's [[Four-ball golf|fourball]] matches 3½ to ½ and extended the lead by taking the afternoon [[foursome (golf)|foursome]] 3 matches to 1. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/golf/leaderboard2/3666148.stm (BBC)] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/golf/3665078.stm (BBC)] * [[ICC Champions Trophy 2004|Cricket, ICC Champions Trophy]]: In pool D, the match between [[England cricket team|England]] and [[Sri Lanka national cricket team|Sri Lanka]] is interrupted by rain with England on 118–3 after 31 overs. The match will resume tomorrow. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/3666882.stm (BBC)] * [[Baseball]]: [[Nippon Professional Baseball]] players announce they will go on strike for the first time in Japan's history. The strike is made in protest of a proposed merger between the [[Orix Blue Wave]] and the [[Kintetsu Buffaloes]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/news/story?id=1883405 (ESPN.com)] * [[Baseball]]: [[Barry Bonds]] hits the 700th [[home run]] of his career in a game against the [[San Diego Padres]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/news/story?id=1883862 (ESPN.com)] * [[Baseball]]: [[Ichiro Suzuki]] of the [[Seattle Mariners]] breaks the [[major league baseball]] record for most singles in a season by hitting his 199th of the year, breaking the record of 198 set by [[Lloyd Waner]] in 1927. ([http://www.canada.com/sports/baseball/story.html?id=c528335e-8176-4482-8021-74987e14a0ca Canada.Com]) * [[Baseball]]: [[Frank Francisco]] of the [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]] gets suspended for the rest of the season, stemming from an altercation where he hit a woman on her nose with a chair in a game against the [[Oakland A's]].
==September 16, 2004 == * [[Football (soccer)]]: [[UEFA]] announce that their disciplinary panel will meet on 21 September to determine [[AS Roma]]'s punishment for the violence which caused last night's [[UEFA Champions League]] match against [[Dynamo Kyiv]] to be abandoned at half time. When there was violence at Roma's ground two years ago at a Champions League match against [[Galatasaray S.K. (football team)|Galatasaray]], also refereed by [[Anders Frisk]], Roma were fined about [[Euro|€]]350 thousand, leading to speculation that there will be a more severe punishment this time. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/3661010.stm (BBC)] * [[Football (soccer)]]: [[Premier League]] club [[Blackburn Rovers]] confirm that they have signed [[Mark Hughes]] as their new manager. Hughes, who takes over from [[Graeme Souness]], had been managing the [[Wales national football team]]. [http://skysports.planetfootball.com/list.asp?hlid=226048&CPID=8&CLID=&lid=2&title=Hughes+thrilled+with+chance (Sky Sports)] *[[UEFA Cup]] 2004–05 First Round, First Leg **[[FK Ventspils|Ventspils]] 1 – 1 [[Amica Wronki]] **[[Wisła Kraków]] 4 – 3 [[FC Dinamo Tbilisi|Dinamo Tbilisi]] **[[Shelbourne FC|Shelbourne]] 2 – 2 [[Lille OSC|Lille]] **[[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa]] 1 – 0 [[FC Dnipro Dnipropetrovsk|Dnipro Dnipropetrovsk]] **[[FC Terek Grozny|Terek Grozny]] 1 – 1 [[FC Basel]] **[[FC Schalke 04|Schalke]] 5 – 1 [[FK Liepājas Metalurgs|Liepājas Metalurgs]] **[[NK Gorica]] 1 – 1 [[AEK Athens F.C.|AEK Athens]] **[[Odd Grenland]] 0 – 1 [[Feyenoord Rotterdam|Feyenoord]] **[[AaB Fodbold|Aalborg]] 1 – 1 [[AJ Auxerre|Auxerre]] **[[Grazer AK]] 5 – 0 [[PFC Litex Lovech|Litex Lovech]] **[[FC Utrecht]] 4 – 0 [[Djurgårdens IF Fotboll|Djurgårdens IF]] **[[PFC Levski Sofia|Levski Sofia]] 1 – 1 [[K.S.K. Beveren|Beveren]] **[[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] 1 – 1 [[Ferencvárosi TC|Ferencváros]] **[[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] 2 – 0 [[Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin FC|Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin]] **[[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Hearts]] 3 – 1 [[S.C Braga|Braga]] **[[FC Metalurh Donetsk|Metalurh Donetsk]] 0 – 3 [[S.S. Benfica|Benfica]] **[[Parma A.C.|Parma]] 3 – 2 [[NK Maribor]] **[[FK Austria Wien|Austria Vienna]] 1 – 0 [[Legia Warszawa]] **[[F.K. F.C.|PAOK Thessaloniki]] 2 – 3 [[AZ Alkmaar]] [http://www.uefa.com/Competitions/UefaCup/index.html (UEFA.com)] * [[ICC Champions Trophy 2004|Cricket, ICC Champions Trophy]]: In pool A, [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] beat [[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]] by seven wickets at [[The Oval]], and qualify for the semi-finals. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/shared/fds/hi/statistics/cricket/scorecards/2004/9/7178/html/scorecard.stm (BBC)]
==September 15, 2004 == * [[National Hockey League]]: In the United States, the NHL board of governors agrees to a [[lockout (industry)|lockout]] of players upon the collapse of [[2004–05 NHL lockout|labor negotiations]] with the [[NHL Players Association]]. This means the 2004–2005 NHL season is suspended until further notice. [https://www.thestar.com/NASApp/cs/ContentServer?pagename=thestar/Layout/Article_Type1&c=Article&cid=1094244389085&call_pageid=968332188492&col=968793972154 (Toronto Star)][http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2004/09/14/nhllabour040914.html (CBC)] *[[UEFA Champions League]], Group Stage, Matchday 1 **Group A: [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] 2 – 0 [[AS Monaco FC|AS Monaco]] **Group A: [[Deportivo de La Coruña|Deportivo La Coruña]] 0 – 0 [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]] **Group B: [[Bayer Leverkusen]] 3 – 0 [[Real Madrid]] **Group B: [[AS Roma]] – [[Dynamo Kyiv]] ***Match abandoned at half time when referee [[Anders Frisk]] was struck by an object. Kyiv were leading 1–0. On September 21, a [[UEFA]] disciplinary panel gave Kyiv a 3–0 forfeit win. **Group C: [[Ajax Amsterdam|Ajax]] 0 – 1 [[Juventus]] **Group C: [[Maccabi Tel Aviv FC|Maccabi Tel Aviv]] 0 – 1 [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]] **Group D: [[Fenerbahçe]] 1 – 0 [[AC Sparta Praha|Sparta Prague]] **Group D: [[Olympique Lyonnais]] 2 – 2 [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] [http://www.uefa.com/Competitions/UCL/index.html (UEFA.com)] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/3661010.stm (BBC)] * [[ICC Champions Trophy 2004|Cricket, ICC Champions Trophy]]: In the pool C match held over from yesterday, [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan]] beat [[Kenyan cricket team|Kenya]] by seven wickets at [[Edgbaston Cricket Ground|Edgbaston]]. Meanwhile, in pool B, the [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies]] beat [[Bangladesh national cricket team|Bangladesh]] by 138 runs at [[Rose Bowl (cricket ground)|The Rose Bowl]]. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/other_international/3652396.stm (BBC)] [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/3656106.stm (BBC)]
==September 14, 2004 == *[[2004 World Cup of Hockey]]: [[Shane Doan]] scores the winning goal as Canada defeats Finland by a score of 3–2 in the tournament final match. *[[UEFA Champions League]] Group Stage Matchday 1 **Group E: [[Panathinaikos F.C.|Panathinaikos]] 2 – 1 [[Rosenborg BK|Rosenborg]] **Group E: [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] 1 – 0 [[PSV Eindhoven|PSV]] **Group F: [[FC Shakhtar Donetsk|Shakhtar Donetsk]] 0 – 1 [[A.C. Milan]] **Group F: [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] 1 – 3 [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] **Group G: [[Valencia, CF|Valencia]] 2 – 0 [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] **Group G: [[Internazionale Milano F.C.|Inter Milan]] 2 – 0 [[Werder Bremen]] **Group H: [[Paris Saint-Germain]] 0 – 3 [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] **Group H: [[F.C. Porto|Porto]] 0 – 0 [[PFC CSKA Moskva|CSKA Moscow]] *[[ICC Champions Trophy 2004|Cricket, ICC Champions Trophy]]: In pool D, [[Sri Lanka national cricket team|Sri Lanka]] beat [[Zimbabwe national cricket team|Zimbabwe]] by 4 wickets at [[The Oval]]. The other scheduled match, between [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan]] and [[Kenyan cricket team|Kenya]], is rained off and will be played tomorrow. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/other_international/3652464.stm (BBC)]
==September 13, 2004 == * [[ICC Champions Trophy 2004|Cricket, ICC Champions Trophy]]: In pool A, [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] beat the [[American cricket team|USA]] by 9 wickets at [[Rose Bowl (cricket ground)|The Rose Bowl]]. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/other_international/3649754.stm (BBC)] * [[Baseball]]: [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]] pitcher [[Frank Francisco]] throws a chair at an [[Oakland Athletics]] fan who was heckling him, starting a bench-clearing brawl. Francisco was arrested for aggravated battery. [http://www.mercurynews.com/mld/mercurynews/9660205.htm?1c (San Jose Mercury)] * [[National Football League]] Week 1, [[Monday Night Football]]: In the first Monday night game of the season, the [[Green Bay Packers]] defeat the defending [[National Football Conference|NFC]] champion [[Carolina Panthers]] 24 to 14. Packers [[fullback (American football)|fullback]] [[Ahman Green]] rushes 33 times for 119 yards and two [[touchdown]]s.
==September 12, 2004 == * [[Tennis]]: [[Roger Federer]] defeats [[Lleyton Hewitt]] 6–0, 7–6, 6–0 to win the [[US Open (tennis)|US Open]] men's singles title in [[Flushing, New York]]. [http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/tennis/usopen04/news/story?id=1880295 (ESPN)] [http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/common/story_page/0,5744,10750408%255E2722,00.html (The Australian)] * [[American football]]: Most [[National Football League]] teams play their Week 1 games: ** [[Joe Gibbs]] wins the first game of his return to coaching as his [[Washington Redskins]] defeat the [[Tampa Bay Buccaneers]] 16–10. [https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/recaps/20040912/tamwas (Yahoo!/AP)] ** The [[Detroit Lions]] break a 24-game road losing streak by beating the [[Chicago Bears]] 20–16. [https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/recap?gid=20040912003 (Yahoo!/AP)] ** [[Terrell Owens]] catches three touchdowns in his first game with the [[Philadelphia Eagles]]. The Eagles defeat the [[New York Giants]] 31–17. [https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/recaps/20040912/nygphi (Yahoo!/AP)] * [[ICC Champions Trophy 2004|Cricket, ICC Champions Trophy]]: In pool B, [[South Africa national cricket team|South Africa]] beat [[Bangladesh national cricket team|Bangladesh]] by 9 wickets at [[Edgbaston Cricket Ground|Edgbaston]]. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/other_international/fixtures/default.stm (BBC)] * [[Formula One]], [[Italian Grand Prix]]: [[Rubens Barrichello]] wins his first race of the season, with [[Ferrari]] teammate [[Michael Schumacher]] second and [[Jenson Button]] third. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/motorsport/formula_one/3649206.stm (BBC)]
==September 11, 2004 == *[[2004 World Cup of Hockey|World Cup of Hockey]]: [[Vincent Lecavalier]] scores at 3:45 in [[overtime (hockey)|overtime]] as Canada advances to the final with a 4–3 win over the Czech Republic in Toronto. The Canadians will take on Finland in the championship game, also in Toronto on September 14. [http://wch2004.com/scores/recaps/118_6_recap.html (WCH website)] * [[ICC Champions Trophy 2004|Cricket, ICC Champions Trophy]]: In the uncompleted pool D match from yesterday, [[England cricket team|England]] beat [[Zimbabwe national cricket team|Zimbabwe]] by 152 runs. In pool C, [[India national cricket team|India]] beat [[Kenyan cricket team|Kenya]] by 98 runs. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/other_international/fixtures/default.stm (BBC)] * [[Boxing]]: [[Miguel Cotto]] defeats [[Kelson Pinto]] by [[technical knockout|TKO]], crowning himself world champion of the [[World Boxing Organization|WBO]] 140 pounds (64 kg) division, while [[Daniel Santos (boxer)|Daniel Santos]] retains his [[World Boxing Organization|WBO]] [[super welterweight]] crown after defeating [[Antonio Margarito]] by [[technical decision]] after ten rounds, at the same undercard, held in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico]].[http://www.boxing-central.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=4906 (Boxing central)] * [[US Open (tennis)|US Open]]: In an all-Russian women's singles final, [[Svetlana Kuznetsova]] beats [[Elena Dementieva]] 6–3 7–5 to win her first Grand Slam title. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/tennis/3646642.stm (BBC)] * [[Horse-racing|Horse racing]]: Rule of Law wins the [[St. Leger Stakes]], the final leg of the [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing|English Triple Crown]], at [[Doncaster Racecourse|Doncaster]]. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/horse_racing/3639262.stm (BBC)] * [[Baseball]]: [[Barry Bonds]] does not become the third player in baseball history to hit 700 home-runs by going one for one with a single against the [[Arizona Diamondbacks]], but he does break his own record for walks in a single season, getting three walks to top the 198 walks he had in 2002, in a [[San Francisco Giants|Giants]] 5–3 win. * [[Basketball]]: The [[University of South Florida]] announces that [[Women|female]] basketball player [[Andrea Armstrong]] will be allowed to play wearing her [[muslim]] attires.
==September 10, 2004 == *[[ICC Champions Trophy 2004|Cricket, ICC Champions Trophy]]: In pool A, [[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]] beat the [[American cricket team|USA]] by 210 runs. The pool D match between [[England cricket team|England]] and [[Zimbabwe national cricket team|Zimbabwe]] is interrupted by rain and will conclude tomorrow. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/statistics/3472979.stm (BBC)] *[[2004 World Cup of Hockey|World Cup of Hockey]]: Finland eliminates the United States with a 2–1 semi-final win in [[St. Paul, Minnesota]]. [[Saku Koivu]] scores the winning goal with less than four minutes left to play in the third period. The Finns will travel to Toronto to play the winner of Saturday's match between Canada and the Czech Republic on September 14. [http://www.wch04.com/scores/boxscores/117_6_boxscore.html (WCH website)]
==September 9, 2004 ==
*[[American football]]: ** The [[National Football League]] season opened with the [[New England Patriots]] defeating the [[Indianapolis Colts]] 27–24 in [[Foxboro, Massachusetts]]. Colts kicker [[Mike Vanderjagt]] missed his first field goal since 2002 in the final 30 seconds. [https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/recap?gid=20040909017 (Yahoo!/AP)] ** The [[National Football League]] announces the game between the [[Miami Dolphins]] and [[Tennessee Titans]], originally scheduled for Sunday, September 12, is being moved to Saturday, September 11 due to the threat of [[Hurricane Ivan]]. The game will be televised in the [[Miami]] and [[Tennessee]] areas only. [http://msn.foxsports.com/story/2999790 (Fox)] *[[Ice hockey]]: The executive committees of the [[National Hockey League]] and [[National Hockey League Players Association]] meet at a secret location in Toronto for [[2004–05 NHL lockout|collective bargaining negotiations]]. The NHLPA submits a proposal that is believed to be similar to the offer it made on October 1, 2003. It is quickly rejected by the league. [http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&cid=565&ncid=1360&e=1&u=/ap/20040910/ap_on_sp_ho_ne/hkn_nhl_labor_talks (AP)] *[[Basketball]]: ** The [[Women's National Basketball Association|WNBA]]'s [[Chamique Holdsclaw]] declares she will not play for the [[Washington Mystics]] for the rest of the year, due to an unspecified [[medicine|medical]] reason.[http://espn.go.com/wnba/news/2004/0908/1877615.html (ESPN)] **[[Lisa Leslie]] of the [[Los Angeles Sparks]] records the WNBA's third triple-double in history, scoring 29 points, grabbing 15 rebounds and tying the WNBA's record of ten blocked shots in one game, as the Sparks defeat the defending champion [[Detroit Shock]], 81–63, in [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]]. [http://www.wnba.com/games/20040909/DETLAS/recap.html (WNBA)]
==September 8, 2004==
*[[2004 World Cup of Hockey|World Cup of Hockey]]: Canada advances to the semi-finals by beating [[Slovakia]] 5–0 in Toronto. Canada will play the Czech Republic, while the United States will play Finland. [http://www.wch04.com/scores/recaps/116_6_recap.html (WCH website)] *[[Basketball]]: The [[Chicago Bulls]] trade [[Dikembe Mutombo]] to the [[Houston Rockets]] for reserve guards [[Adrian Griffin]], [[Eric Piatkowski]] and [[Mike Wilks (basketball)|Mike Wilks]]. [http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2004/basketball/nba/09/08/mutombo.ap/index.html (CNNSI/AP)]
==September 7, 2004 ==
*[[2004 World Cup of Hockey|World Cup of Hockey]]: In [[Stockholm]], the Czech Republic routs Sweden 6–1 to advance to the semi-finals in North America. The United States also advance largely due to the play of [[Keith Tkachuk]], who scores four goals in a 5–3 win over Russia in [[St. Paul, Minnesota]]. [http://www.wch04.com/scores/recaps/114_6_recap.html (WCH website)] [http://www.wch04.com/scores/recaps/115_6_recap.html (WCH website)]
==September 6, 2004 ==
*[[Football (soccer)|Football]]: [[Graeme Souness]] resigns as manager of [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] to take over the vacant post at [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]. Newcastle had dismissed their previous manager, Sir [[Bobby Robson]] on August 30. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/n/newcastle_united/3630952.stm (BBC)] *[[2004 World Cup of Hockey|World Cup of Hockey]]: In [[Helsinki]], Finland survive a scare from Germany to win their quarter-final match 2–1 on a late goal from [[Mikko Eloranta]]. The Finns will now travel to North America for their semi-final match. [http://www.wch04.com/scores/recaps/113_6_recap.html (WCH website)] *[[Baseball]]: The [[New York Yankees]] ask for a forfeit in the first game of a doubleheader against the [[Tampa Bay Devil Rays]]. The Devil Rays were late getting to [[Yankee Stadium (1923)|Yankee Stadium]] after delays caused by [[Hurricane Frances]]. Commissioner [[Bud Selig]] denies the request, and says a make-up game will be held on October 4 if required. The Yankees win the only game played, 7–4. [http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2004/baseball/mlb/09/06/bc.bba.devilrays.travel.ap/index.html (CNNSI/AP)] *[[Vijay Singh]] wins [[golf]]'s Deutsche Bank Championship to go to the top of the world rankings. He ends [[Tiger Woods]] reign of five years and four weeks. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/golf/3633256.stm (BBC)]
==September 5, 2004 ==
*[[2004 World Cup of Hockey|World Cup of Hockey]]: In the final North American group match, Russia defeats [[Slovakia]] 5–2 in Toronto. The Russians finish 2–1 and will travel to [[St. Paul, Minnesota]] to play the United States in the quarter-finals. The Slovaks finish 0–3 and will remain in Toronto to face Canada in the other quarter-final match. [http://wch2004.com/scores/recaps/112_6_recap.html (WCH website)]
==September 4, 2004 ==
* [[Boxing]]: Former world Welterweight champion [[Ricardo Mayorga]] is arrested at [[Managua International Airport]] in [[Managua, Nicaragua]], charged with the [[rape]] of a twenty-year-old woman, and putting his October 2 fight with [[Félix Trinidad]] in serious jeopardy. [http://www.boxing-central.com/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=4854 (BoxingCentral)] * [[American football]]: [[De La Salle High School (Concord, California)|De La Salle High School]] of [[Concord, California]] loses to [[Bellevue High School (Washington)|Bellevue High School]] of [[Bellevue, Washington]] 39–20, ending De La Salle's record 151-game winning streak dating back to 1991. [http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/news/story?id=1875067 (ESPN)] [http://www.dailynews.com/Stories/0,1413,200~29583~2383255,00.html (Los Angeles Daily News)] *[[2004 World Cup of Hockey|World Cup of Hockey]]: Canada finishes atop the North American pool standings with a 3–0 record after they defeat Russia 3–1 in Toronto. The Russians drop to 1–1. In the European pool, Sweden ties Finland 4–4 in [[Helsinki]] and both teams finish the group stage with a 2–0–1 record. The Finns earn top spot due to their superior [[goal difference]] and will host Germany in the quarter-finals, while the Swedes will host the Czech Republic. [http://wch2004.com/scores/recaps/110_6_recap.html (WCH website)] [http://wch2004.com/scores/recaps/111_6_recap.html (WCH website)]
==September 3, 2004 ==
*[[2004 World Cup of Hockey|World Cup of Hockey]]: In the North American pool, the United States defeats [[Slovakia]] 3–1 in [[St. Paul, Minnesota]]. The Americans finish the group stage with a 1–2 record, while the Slovaks drop to 0–2. In the European pool, the Czech Republic also earn their first win of the tournamentwith a 7–2 win over Germany in [[Prague]]. The Czechs finish round-robin play with a 1–2 record, while the Germans finish 0–3. [http://wch2004.com/scores/recaps/108_6_recap.html (WCH website)][http://wch2004.com/scores/recaps/109_6_recap.html (WCH website)]
==September 2, 2004 == * [[Rugby union]]: England national team coach [[Clive Woodward|Sir Clive Woodward]] resigns, after having been dissuaded from doing so yesterday. [[Andy Robinson]] is named acting coach of England. Woodward has expressed his interest in switching codes to [[Football (soccer)|soccer]]. The media reports that he may be appointed to a role at [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton Football Club]]. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/rugby_union/international/3613610.stm (BBC (1))], [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/southampton/3616864.stm (BBC (2))] * [[2004 World Cup of Hockey|World Cup of Hockey]]: Russia wins its opening North American pool match against the United States by a 3–1 score in [[St. Paul, Minnesota]], dropping the Americans to 0–2. Finland records a 3–0 win against Germany in a European group match in [[Cologne]], improving the Finns to 2–0 and ensuring home-ice advantage for themselves and Sweden in the quarter-finals. The Germans drop to 0–2. [http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&cid=1841&ncid=1841&e=4&u=/cpress/20040902/ca_pr_on_sp/hky_wcup_ger_fin (AP)][http://story.news.yahoo.com/news?tmpl=story&cid=1820&ncid=1820&e=1&u=/cpress/20040903/ca_pr_on_ho/hky_wcup_rus_us (CP)]
==September 1, 2004 == * [[Horse racing]]: In early morning raids by 130 officers in three counties, British police arrest three jockeys including champion jockey [[Kieren Fallon]], a trainer, and twelve other people as part of a long-running investigation into [[race-fixing]]. [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/other_sports/horse_racing/3616748.stm (BBC)] * [[2004 World Cup of Hockey|World Cup of Hockey]]: Canada defeats [[Slovakia]] 5–1 in a North American pool match in [[Montreal]], improving the Canadians to 2–0 and dropping the Slovaks to 0–1. In the European group match in [[Stockholm]], Sweden defeats the Czech Republic 4–3 and moves to 2–0, while the Czechs drop to 0–2. [http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Hockey/WorldCup/2004/09/01/612064.html (AP)]
